trans-unit.source: Represents a selectable option displayed on a <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MenuStrip"></xref> or <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ContextMenuStrip"></xref>.

Although <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem"></xref> replaces and adds functionality to the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MenuItem"></xref> control of previous versions, <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MenuItem"></xref> is retained for both backward compatibility and future use if you choose.

<xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem> is a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripDropDownItem> that works with <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripDropDownMenu> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ContextMenuStrip> to handle the special highlighting, layout, and column arrangement for menus.
In order for a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem> to be displayed, you must add it to a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MenuStrip> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ContextMenuStrip>.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem> class provides properties that enable you to configure the appearance and functionality of a menu item.
To display a check mark next to a menu item, use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem.Checked%2A> property.
Use this feature to identify a menu item that is selected in a list of mutually exclusive menu items.

For example, if you have a set of menu items for setting the color of text in a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TextBox> control, use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem.Checked%2A> property to identify which color is currently selected.
Use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem.ShortcutKeys%2A> property to define a keyboard combination that can be pressed to select the menu item.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem"></xref> class.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem"></xref> class that displays the specified <xref href="System.Drawing.Image"></xref>.
Use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem.%23ctor%2A> constructor to create a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem> that displays an image in the margin alongside the text.
The <xref href="System.Drawing.Image"></xref> to display on the control.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem"></xref> class that displays the specified text.
Use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem.%23ctor%2A> constructor to create a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem> with the specified name.
The text to display on the menu item.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem"></xref> class that displays the specified text and image.
Use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem.%23ctor%2A> constructor to create a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem> with the specified name and image.
The text to display on the menu item.
The <xref href="System.Drawing.Image"></xref> to display on the control.

Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem"></xref> class that displays the specified text and image and that does the specified action when the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem"></xref> is clicked.

Use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem.%23ctor%2A> to create a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem> that displays both text and an image and that does the specified action when the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem> is clicked.
The text to display on the menu item.
The <xref href="System.Drawing.Image"></xref> to display on the control.
An event handler that raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.Click"></xref> event when the control is clicked.

Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem"></xref> class that displays the specified text and image and that contains the specified <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripItem"></xref> collection.

Use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem.%23ctor%2A> constructor to create a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem> that displays text and an image and that contains the specified <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripItem> collection.
The text to display on the menu item.
The <xref href="System.Drawing.Image"></xref> to display on the control.
The menu items to display when the control is clicked.

Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem"></xref> class with the specified name that displays the specified text and image that does the specified action when the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem"></xref> is clicked.
The text to display on the menu item.
The <xref href="System.Drawing.Image"></xref> to display on the control.
An event handler that raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.Click"></xref> event when the control is clicked.
The name of the menu item.

Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem"></xref> class that displays the specified text and image, does the specified action when the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem"></xref> is clicked, and displays the specified shortcut keys.

Use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem.%23ctor%2A> constructor to create a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem> that displays text and an image, performs the specified action when clicked, and has the specified shortcut key.
The text to display on the menu item.
The <xref href="System.Drawing.Image"></xref> to display on the control.
An event handler that raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.Click"></xref> event when the control is clicked.
One of the values of <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Keys"></xref> that represents the shortcut key for the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem"></xref>.
Gets or sets a value indicating whether the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem"></xref> is checked.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem.Checked%2A> property returns `false` if and only if the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem> is unchecked.
Starting with the .NET Framework 4.5.2, when an item is checked or indeterminate, the corresponding icon may be resized.
Resizing is determined by the system DPI setting when the app.config file contains the following entry:
`true` if the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem"></xref> is checked or is in an indeterminate state; otherwise, `false`.
The default is `false`.
Occurs when the value of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem.Checked"></xref> property changes.
For more information about handling events, see [Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b6f65241-e0ad-4590-a99f-200ce741bb1f).
Gets or sets a value indicating whether the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem"></xref> should automatically appear checked and unchecked when clicked.
`true` if the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem"></xref> should automatically appear checked when clicked; otherwise, `false`.
The default is `false`.
Gets or sets a value indicating whether a <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem"></xref> is in the checked, unchecked, or indeterminate state.

Use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem.CheckState%2A> property to control or determine whether a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem> is initially checked, unchecked, or in an indeterminate state.

Starting with the .NET Framework 4.5.2, if the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem.CheckState%2A> property is set to <xref:System.Windows.Forms.CheckState.Checked> or <xref:System.Windows.Forms.CheckState.Indeterminate>, the corresponding icon may be resized.
Resizing is determined by the system DPI setting when the app.config file contains the following entry:
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.CheckState"></xref> values.
The default is `Unchecked`.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem.CheckState"></xref> property is not set to one of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.CheckState"></xref> values.
Occurs when the value of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem.CheckState"></xref> property changes.
For more information about handling events, see [Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b6f65241-e0ad-4590-a99f-200ce741bb1f).
Creates a new accessibility object for the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem"></xref>.
A new <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AccessibleObject"></xref> for the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem"></xref>.
Creates a generic <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripDropDown"></xref> for which events can be defined.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem.CreateDefaultDropDown%2A> method is automatically called if the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripDropDownItem.DropDown%2A> property finds no <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripDropDown> associated with the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripDropDownItem>.
A generic <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripDropDown"></xref> for which can be defined.
Gets the spacing between the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem"></xref> and an adjacent item.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Padding"></xref> value representing the spacing.
Gets the internal spacing within the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem"></xref>.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Padding"></xref> value representing the spacing.
Gets the default size of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem"></xref>.
Override <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem.DefaultSize%2A> in derived classes to configure a default size for a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem>.
This is more efficient than setting the size in the control's constructor.
The <xref href="System.Drawing.Size"></xref> of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem"></xref>, measured in pixels.
The default is 100 pixels horizontally.
Releases the unmanaged resources used by the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem"></xref> and optionally releases the managed resources.
This method is called by the public `Dispose` method and the <xref:System.Object.Finalize%2A> method.
`Dispose` invokes the protected `Dispose(Boolean)` method with the `disposing` parameter set to `true`.
<xref:System.Object.Finalize%2A> invokes `Dispose` with `disposing` set to `false`.
When the `disposing` parameter is true, this method releases all resources held by any managed objects that this <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem> references.
This method invokes the `Dispose` method of each referenced object.
`true` to release both managed and unmanaged resources; `false` to release only unmanaged resources.
Gets or sets a value indicating whether the control is enabled.
`true` if the control is enabled; otherwise, `false`.
The default is `true`.
Gets a value indicating whether the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem"></xref> appears on a multiple document interface (MDI) window list.
The name of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem> must be specified by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.MenuStrip.MdiWindowListItem%2A> property.
`true` if the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem"></xref> appears on a MDI window list; otherwise, `false`.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem.CheckedChanged"></xref> event.
Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate.
For more information, see [Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b6f65241-e0ad-4590-a99f-200ce741bb1f).
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem.OnCheckedChanged%2A> method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate.
This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
An <xref href="System.EventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem.CheckStateChanged"></xref> event.
Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate.
For more information, see [Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b6f65241-e0ad-4590-a99f-200ce741bb1f).
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem.OnCheckStateChanged%2A> method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate.
This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
An <xref href="System.EventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripItem.Click"></xref> event.
Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate.
For more information, see [Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b6f65241-e0ad-4590-a99f-200ce741bb1f).
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem.OnClick%2A> method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate.
This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
An <xref href="System.EventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Raised in response to the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripDropDownItem.HideDropDown"></xref> method.
Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate.
For more information, see [Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b6f65241-e0ad-4590-a99f-200ce741bb1f).
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem.OnDropDownHide%2A> method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate.
This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
An <xref href="System.EventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Raised in response to the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripDropDownItem.ShowDropDown"></xref> method.
Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate.
For more information, see [Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b6f65241-e0ad-4590-a99f-200ce741bb1f).
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem.OnDropDownShow%2A> method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate.
This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
An <xref href="System.EventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.FontChanged"></xref> event.
An <xref href="System.EventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.MouseDown"></xref> event.
Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate.
For more information, see [Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b6f65241-e0ad-4590-a99f-200ce741bb1f).
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem.OnMouseDown%2A> method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate.
This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MouseEventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.MouseEnter"></xref> event.
Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate.
For more information, see [Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b6f65241-e0ad-4590-a99f-200ce741bb1f).
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem.OnMouseEnter%2A> method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate.
This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
An <xref href="System.EventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.MouseLeave"></xref> event.
Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate.
For more information, see [Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b6f65241-e0ad-4590-a99f-200ce741bb1f).
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem.OnMouseLeave%2A> method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate.
This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
An <xref href="System.EventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripItem.MouseUp"></xref> event.
Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate.
For more information, see [Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b6f65241-e0ad-4590-a99f-200ce741bb1f).
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem.OnMouseUp%2A> method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate.
This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.MouseEventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripItem.OwnerChanged"></xref> event.
Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate.
For more information, see [Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b6f65241-e0ad-4590-a99f-200ce741bb1f).
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem.OnOwnerChanged%2A> method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate.
This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
An <xref href="System.EventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.
Raises the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.Paint"></xref> event.
Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate.
For more information, see [Events](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/b6f65241-e0ad-4590-a99f-200ce741bb1f).
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem.OnPaint%2A> method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate.
This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
An <xref href="System.EventArgs"></xref> that contains the event data.

Gets or sets a value indicating whether the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem"></xref> is attached to the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStrip"></xref> or the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripOverflowButton"></xref> or whether it can float between the two.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripItemOverflow"></xref> values.
The default is `Never`.
Processes a command key.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Message"></xref>, passed by reference, which represents the window message to process.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Keys"></xref> values that represents the key to process.
`true` if the character was processed by the control; otherwise, `false`.
Processes a mnemonic character.
The character to process.
`true` if the character was processed as a mnemonic by the control; otherwise, `false`.
Sets the size and location of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem"></xref>.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.Rectangle"></xref> that represents the size and location of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem"></xref>.
Gets or sets the shortcut key text.
Use this property to get or set the text that is displayed as the shortcut key.
A <xref href="System.String"></xref> representing the shortcut key.
Gets or sets the shortcut keys associated with the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem"></xref>.
Use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem.ShortcutKeys%2A> property to assign a key combination to a menu command, such as CTRL+C for the **Copy** command.
You can use shortcut keys instead of or in addition to access keys, which are underscored letters in menus or menu items used with the ALT key.
Define access keys in code by typing an ampersand (&) before the letter you want to use for an access key.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Keys"></xref> values.
The default is <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Keys.None"></xref>.
The property was not set to one of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Keys"></xref> values.

Gets or sets a value indicating whether the shortcut keys that are associated with the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem"></xref> are displayed next to the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ToolStripMenuItem"></xref>.
`true` if the shortcut keys are shown; otherwise, `false`.
The default is `true`.
